Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Empowering the Scientific Community with Streaming Data Middleware: Software Integration into Complex Science Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will catalyze a new generation of sensor-based streaming data applications by building on the foundation of the Open Source DataTurbine (OSDT) middleware (www.dataturbine.org). This will involve strategic software development, systems integration and testing, science experiments, and education and outreach. The software developments will include (A) tools for configuring, testing, and controlling distributed sensor systems, (B) software interfaces that are compliant with the Open Geospatial Consortium Sensor Web Enablement standards, (C) a new OSDT-Matlab interface, and (D) OSDT cybersecurity enhancements. These software products will be integrated into the production research infrastructures at Purdue, the University of Connecticut, the North Temperate Lake LTER Network site, and the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute. The software will be professionally developed and managed as community resources. The intellectual merit of this project will be advances in software engineering, interoperability standards, and systems management for complex real-time sensor systems as well as advances on important open questions in civil engineering, marine science, and ecology. This project will yield broader impacts by enabling new science applications, enhancing productivity, and accelerating innovation across NSF directorates. To ensure that these broader impacts are realized, the team will provide student research opportunities, develop curriculum materials and training courses, and cultivate a community of software users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Open Source DataTurbine middleware software is a significant tool for meeting the challenges of measurement, recording, and data distribution of widely distributed environmental and scientific sensors. A diverse group of collaborators comprising the OSDT Initiative team leveraged DataTurbine middleware to develop and demonstrate interconnected data collection and monitoring applications, along with the software tools and documented expertise to maintain, operate, and extend associated state of the art systems.

Scientists from UCSD, home of the project PI, coordinated activities and provided support and resources to a wide range of scientific communities via the dataturbine.org website, mailing list, software repository, code maintenance, publications, training, application integration, and demonstrations. Related efforts developed links between DataTurbine and Community Inventory of EarthCube Resources for Geosciences Interoperability (CINERGI).

The Northern Temperate Lakes (NTL) Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) group developed and demonstrated real time data acquisition for remote monitoring of long-term change and alerting short-term fluctuations in lake conditions. A Matlab Toolkit linking DataTurbine to this powerful data analysis tool was developed. A workshop was held to train members of the ecological community in the use of these tools.

Researchers from Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) focused on ocean observing system applications. The MBARI group used DataTurbine and the related new-generation CloudTurbine software to store, share, and view data from ocian acidification measurements during Free Ocean CO2 Enrichment (FOCE) experiments in Monterey Bay. Data was archived and distributed using cloud-based file sharing services. The WebScan software with enhancements on this project enabled scientists and engineers to view instrument data and video remotely in real time, using a web browser.

Engineering researchers at Purdue/UConn advanced the state of the art in distributed, real-time hybrid simulation, including millisecond-level control-loop feedback control between computing and structural systems widely separated on the Purdue and UConn campuses. DataTurbine middleware was performance tested and found to sustain the high-rate data and provide advantages for improving data correlation between sites. Experiments were performed that focused on performance assessment of structural systems designed to mitigate seismic hazards. Educational efforts also exploited the use of Data Turbine middleware to execute tele-operation experiments using seismic simulator tables. Undergraduate students in Cali, Colombia, South America used remote shake tables at Purdue University to learn about structural dynamics and earthquake responses.

To ensure the sustainability of the DataTurbine Initiative community, the products and resources of the project have been transitioned to the public domain. These products and resources include the website, code repository, documentation and tutorials. Cycronix, the home of the original developer of the DataTurbine software, has assumed responsibility for managing these resources for the immediate future. This arrangement will support the existing DataTurbine projects and also encourage new developments and applications that will benefit from the outcomes of this SI2 project.
